developmentContext.title: Development Context
developmentContext.content:
Singapore is a high-income country in Southeast Asia at the southern tip of the Malay Peninsula, with one main island, an outlying inlet, and 63 satellite islands and islets. Singapore is a developed country ranked ninth by Human Development Index and has the second highest GDP per capita in the world, with a population of 5.7 million people. From its history as a transshipment port, Singapore has a highly developed market economy which is considered to be innovative and dynamic, resulting in significant foreign investment, leading to a ranking as the most competitive economy by the World Economic forum. Diversification is at the heart of Singapore’s Economy with bases in finance, trade and transportation. In 2019, the industry made up approximately a quarter of the country’s GDP while the rest was covered by the services sector with service exports (mainly manufactured goods, electronics and machinery) amounting to almost twice the GDP.

Singapore supports the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). It presented its first Voluntary National Review (VNR) report to the 2018 High-Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development. The VNR process was co-led by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Sustainability and the Environment and took stock of progress on sustainable development. Singapore’s 2018 VNR reflects its domestic and international efforts to implement the 2030 Agenda, in particular areas such as water and sanitation and sustainable cities.

successesInDevelopment.title: Successes in Development
successesInDevelopment.content: Singapore’s HDI value for 2019 is 0.938— which puts the country in the very high human development category—positioning it at 11 out of 189 countries and territories. Between 1990 and 2019, Singapore’s HDI value increased from 0.721 to 0.938, an increase of 30.1 percent. In that same time period, Singapore’s life expectancy at birth increased by 7.7 years, mean years of schooling increased by 5.8 years and expected years of schooling increased by 5.8 years. Singapore’s GNI per capita also increased by about 137.8 percent between 1990 and 2019. Singapore has also made strides in gender equality with a GII value of 0.065, ranking it 12 out of 162 countries in the 2019 index. 23.0 percent of the country’s parliamentary seats are held by women, and 78.1 percent of adult women have reached at least a secondary level of education compared to 85.1 percent of their male counterparts. Female participation in the labour market has also significantly improved coming in at 62.0 percent compared to 78.3 for men.

challengesInDevelopment.title: Challenges in Development
challengesInDevelopment.content:
As a small island city-state with limited land and natural resources, Singapore faces some development challenges similar to other SIDS countries such as dependence on import of goods. It’s population also grew from 4 to 4.84 million in less than a decade and is set to grow further in the future. Such growth will place heavier demands on limited resources, and increase the potential for pollution if development is not managed well.

//////////////////////////////////////////////////////

MCO office: https://www1.undp.org/content/singapore-global-centre/en/home.html (No narrative)

# 1 sustainable city in Asia

#1 most innovative country in Asia and #8 worldwide

#3 competitive economy worldwide

>4000 tech startups

As the number one sustainable city in Asia and one of the most innovative countries in the world, it has the number 3 ranked competitive economy worldwide and is home to over 4000 tech startups. It is also home to the Global Centre for Technology, Innovation and Sustainable Development , the joint initiative by the Government of Singapore and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP).

Country Program Document: N/A

SDG: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/UNSDG/countryprofiles/sgp

The annual growth rate of real gross domestic product (GDP) per capita declined from 6.9 % in 2000 to 2.3% in 2018.

In 2018, 95.0 % of the population relied primarily on clean fuels and technology .

Fixed-broadband internet penetration reached increased from 1.7 per 100 inhabitants in 2000 to 28.0 per 100 inhabitants in 2018.

In 2018, 100.0 % of the population were covered by at least a 4G mobile network

Land area covered by forest declined from 24.0 % in 2000 to 22.0% in 2020.

The extension of protected marine area was 0.1 square km in 2018.

Sustainable Development UN: https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/memberstates/singapore

HDR: https://hdr.undp.org/en/countries/profiles/SGP#

2- Human Development Index (HDI)

Singapore’s HDI value for 2019 is 0.938— which put the country in the very high human development category—positioning it at 11 out of 189 countries and territories. The rank is shared with Finland.

Between 1990 and 2019, Singapore’s HDI value increased from 0.721 to 0.938, an increase of 30.1 percent. Table A reviews Singapore’s progress in each of the HDI indicators. Between 1990 and 2019, Singapore’s life expectancy at birth increased by 7.7 years, mean years of schooling increased by 5.8 years and expected years of schooling increased by 5.8 years. Singapore’s GNI per capita increased by about 137.8 percent between 1990 and 2019.

4- Gender Development Index (GDI)

The 2019 female HDI value for Singapore is 0.931 in contrast with 0.945 for males, resulting in a GDI value of 0.985, placing it into Group 1.

Gender Inequality Index (GII)

Singapore has a GII value of 0.065, ranking it 12 out of 162 countries in the 2019 index. In Singapore, 23.0 percent of parliamentary seats are held by women, and 78.1 percent of adult women have reached at least a secondary level of education compared to 85.1 percent of their male counterparts. For every 100,000 live births, 8.0 women die from pregnancy related causes; and the adolescent birth rate is 3.5 births per 1,000 women of ages 15-19. Female participation in the labour market is 62.0 percent compared to 78.3 for men
